tool.name: Loca_vic_Data

param.name: Climate Model
param.expression: ACCESS1-0 | ACCESS1-3 | bcc-csm1-1 | bcc-csm1-1-m | CanESM2 | CCSM4 | CESM1-BGC | CESM1-CAM5 | CMCC-CM | CMCC-CMS | CNRM-CM5 | CSIRO-Mk3-6-0 | EC-EARTH | FGOALS-g2 | GFDL-CM3 | GFDL-ESM2G | GFDL-ESM2M | GISS-E2-H | GISS-E2-R | HadGEM2-AO | HadGEM2-CC | HadGEM2-ES | inmcm4 | IPSL-CM5A-LR | IPSL-CM5A-MR | MIROC5 | MIROC-ESM | MIROC-ESM-CHEM | MPI-ESM-LR | MPI-ESM-MR | MRI-CGCM3 | NorESM1-M
param.dialogReference: Global Climatic Models (GCM) you would like to query using the CalAdapt API. A list of GCMs from CalAdapt API (https://berkeley-gif.github.io/caladapt-docs/data-catalog.html#global-climate-models-gcm).

param.name: Climate Scenario
param.dialogReference: To learn more about Representative Concentration Pathways (RCPs) go here.

param.name: variables
param.expression: albedo | baseflow | del_SWE | ET | latent | longwave_net | pet_natveg | precip | Qair | rainfall | relHumid | runoff | sensible | shortwave_in | shortwave_net | snow_melt | snowfall | soilMoist1 | soilMoist2 | soilMoist3 | sublimation_net | SWE | Tair | tot_runoff | wdew | windspeed
param.dialogReference: Climatic Variables you would like to download from the Cal-Adapt Data Server. A list of climate variables from CalAdapt (https://cal-adapt.org/data/loca-vic/).

param.name: start year
param.dialogReference: Choose the first (or only) year to download (Historic: years available 1950-2013, RCP# years available 2006-2100)

param.name: end year
param.dialogReference: Choose the last year (if downloading a range) to download (Historic: years available 1950-2013, RCP# years available 2006-2100)

param.name: outLoc
param.dialogReference: Where would you like the data saved.

tool.summary:
Download the SCRIPPS Additional VIC Variables (forced by LOCA) as NetCDF files from the Cal-Adapt Data Server.

LOCA downscaled projections of daily precipitation and minimum and maximum temperature are used to drive a land surface/hydrology model, the Variable Infiltration Capacity (VIC) Model to provide high-resolution projections for a suite of hydrological parameters. The VIC model was originally developed by Xu Liang at the University of Washington. Development and maintenance of the current official version of the VIC model is led by the UW Hydro | Computational Hydrology group in the Department of Civil and Environmental Engineering at the University of Washington.

dataIdInfo.idCredit: Created by Shane T. Feirer of the UCANR Informatics and GIS Program (IGIS).
